ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

KAMPONG GLAM CONSTITUENCY
(Neighbourhood Police Post)


    The following question stood in the name of Mr Loh Meng See -

    1. To ask the Minister for Home Affairs (a) when will a neighbourhood police post be set up in Kampong Glam Constituency; and (b) in view of the geographical structure of the Kampong Glam Constituency, whether the Constituency can have two neighbourhood police posts, one covering the Crawford/Beach Road area and the other the Waterloo Street/Queen Street area.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Cheng San GRC): Question No. 1, Sir.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, Kampong Glam Constituency is scheduled to have a Neighbourhood Police Post (NPP) in 1989. However, there is a problem in finding a permanent site because of the built-up nature of the area and the non-availability of HDB ground floor void decks.

    Until a permanent site is found, a temporary NPP will be set up at the vacant land next to Block 17, Beach Road, during the course of this year.

    As for the second part of the question, the Police have studied whether the Constituency requires more than one NPP and they have assessed that the area can be covered by one NPP.

JIM II
(Report)


    3. Dr Ong Chit Chung asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will report on the outcome of 'JIM II' and comment on the prospects for a peaceful settlement in Cambodia.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, my assessment of JIM II was already published in the Straits Times on 24th February, and during the Committee of Supply debate on Foreign Affairs I have also given additional information. Nevertheless, I would like to summarize my conclusions.

    We are satisfied with the outcome, but we are realistic about the prospects. Despite the differences, JIM II had spelt out the basic elements of a political solution, including such key points as the withdrawal of the Vietnamese forces, International Control Mechanism and national reconciliation. After our extensive discussions, in Jakarta, the positions of the various parties have become clearer. But there are still more negotiations ahead on the details and the practical implementation of the broad principles set out in the Chairman's Consensus Statement.

    Sir, a political solution or settlement in Cambodia is only a matter of time. But further discussions and negotiations will be necessary. The inter-Khmer talks are likely to be difficult. Hun Sen has hardened his position on power-sharing among the four Cambodian parties and rejected an effective International Control Mechanism. It is my hope that all parties will show flexibility so that a political solution can be reached quickly and the suffering of the Cambodian people can end.

     Dr Ong Chit Chung (Bukit Batok): Sir, has the position of the Thai Prime Minister regarding the Hun Sen government put Asean in a difficult situation and some of the Cambodian factions in an even more delicate position?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, from what I understand, especially during the last few days after the Thai Prime Minister met many Chinese leaders, there has been no

HAWKERS SUMMONED ON CHINESE NEW YEAR'S EVE


    The following question stood in the name of Mr Goh Choon Kang -

    4. To ask the Minister for the Environment (a) how how many licensed hawkers were summoned for "spill-over" of goods at their stalls on 4th February, 1989 (Chinese New Year's Eve) and where; and (b) how many illegal hawkers were summoned on the same day and where.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Question No. 4, Sir.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng) (for the Minister for the Environment): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Every Lunar New Year period, the Hawkers Department gives a concession to stallholders in hawker centres to display their goods beyond their stalls, so long as extensions do not cause obstruction to other stallholders or inconvenience the public. However, no stallholder is allowed to set up stalls outside of the hawker centre proper. If he sets up stalls on the road or public concourse, then he will be given a summons for illegal hawking.

    Sir, on the 4th February 1989, that is, Chinese New Year's Eve, no licensed hawkers were summoned for displaying goods beyond their stalls. This includes hawkers at the Lim Tua Tow Market. A total of 38 illegal hawkers were summoned for selling goods at various places on the 4th February 1989. 19 of them were found selling outside various markets.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee: If no hawker was fined on Lunar New Year's Eve for extension of stall, how does he account for the raid and exorbitant fine on hawkers at Lim Tua Tow Market, as mentioned in this House by the Senior Parliamentary Secretary some days ago?

Column: 662



     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Sir, the point raised by the Member for Braddell Heights in Parliament on 16th March 1989 was that for three consecutive days during the Lunar New Year our officers raided the Lim Tua Tow Market and issued summonses to stallholders who had extended their stalls.

    Sir, may I have your permission to clarify that the Ministry did not issue any summons against stallholders in the Lim Tua Tow Market for extension of stalls during the three days preceding the Lunar New Year. In fact, Members of this House may wish to know that no single summons was issued to stallholders at this market for extension of stalls for 11 clear days before the Lunar New Year. However, three illegal hawkers operating outside the Lim Tua Tow Market were summoned on the eve of Chinese New Year. These three illegal hawkers were not licensed stallholders in the Lim Tua Tow Market. They were there actually to take the business away from the licensed stallholders.

    Sir, the Member for Braddell Heights also informed the House on 16th March that one of the Lim Tua Tow stallholders was fined $800 for extension. Sir, our records show that the highest fine imposed by the court on a stallholder in the Lim Tua Tow Market is $500, and not $800. The stallholder was fined $500 for massive extension on the 24th January 1989 and not on Chinese New Year's Eve because he is recalcitrant - having been fined by the courts on two previous occasions for similar offence of grossly extending his stall and blocking almost the entire passageway, causing gross inconvenience to members of the public. We do not single out any market for special treatment, especially the Lim Tua Tow Market for enforcement action on extension of stalls.

    During the last six months, a total of 69 stallholders from 21 other markets/food centres were summoned for extending their stalls. But during the last six months, four stallholders at Lim Tua Tow Market, including the two recalcitrants, were summoned for extending their stalls.

NEW POPULATION POLICY
(Review)


    7. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Acting Minister for Health (a) whether our population target will be revised with a view to reducing future burden of the aged dependency ratio in the population; and (b) what will be the feasible population target in the long run.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry of Health projects that the aged dependency ratio, which is the ratio of persons aged 60 and over to persons aged 15 to 59, will rise from 0.13 in 1990 to about 0.46 in the year 2030, ie, from about eight working-age persons supporting one elderly to about two working-age persons supporting one elderly. This computation is based on the assumption that the total fertility rate will remain at an average of 1.8 and that the population will grow to about 3.2 million by the year 2025 before it starts to decline.

    The objective of the New Population Policy is to raise the total fertility rate to replacement level by 1995, from its 1987 level of 1.64. If we are able to achieve this target, and maintain it on a long-term basis, the population will grow and stabilize at about 3.5 million by the year 2030. The ageing of our population will then be slowed slightly, and the aged dependency ratio will increase to 0.43 by the year 2030 before declining thereafter to about 0.40.

    Question again proposed.

     Dr Wan Soon Bee (Pasir Panjang GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, before the House adjourned yesterday afternoon, I was talking about the hefty diesel tax increase and that the Public Transport Council had only approved a 20-cent taxi fare increase. Therefore, the total burden of this tax increase was borne by the taxi drivers. As such, their income has been drastically reduced and 20,000 taxi drivers and their families are adversely affected.

Column: 666



    I was also talking about the importance of taxis as a public mode of transport and that it was the second largest public transport to serve Singaporeans and tourists. Although taxis do provide the comfort and convenience not unlike that of private cars, but taxis are not private transport and therefore they should not be treated like private cars in terms of social cost. Therefore, the question of normalizing the differential treatment of the private cars and the taxis does not arise. I agree with what the Member for Fengshan said during the debate on the Presidential Address - that the diesel tax was introduced mainly for private diesel cars; and therefore it has nothing to do with the taxis which are serving the public as such.

    The Government has announced its intention to increase the diesel tax further in November this year and the total amount will be $6,600. After this increase, the operating cost of the taxi drivers will be increased by about $15 a day compared to the pre-November 1988 days. I would also like to point out that come end of this year, the

    eastern line of the MRT will be operational. With a full MRT system running, this is expected to impact considerably on the demand for taxis. Taxi drivers will therefore be dealt, a double blow. Are we fair to these cabbies who also contribute to our economy and form a valuable segment of our workforce?

    I would also like to highlight the hardship that would be suffered by the taxi driver and his family should he fall ill or his vehicle meets with an accident. The taxi driver would not be able to have earnings for a period of time, and yet somehow he must find additional money to pay for the hefty increase in diesel tax.

    For all these reasons, I therefore appeal to the Minister for Communications and Information for greater compassion and understanding on the diesel tax issue. I would urge the Minister to defer the decision to impose the second increase of tax in November and review the situation in consultation with the GPC for Communications and Information and the various taxi organizations.

    I would also like to ask the Minister to consider exempting the taxi operators

Column: 667

from paying diesel tax during the period when the taxis are in the workshop for repairs and when they scrap their cars in the beginning of the month. The monthly diesel tax works out to be $500-$600 and it is a substantial amount which the taxi drivers have to pay although they may not be using the cars during that period. But if the Minister cannot agree to my requests, perhaps it is time that the Minister consider allowing the taxi organizations to determine their own taxi fares and let market forces determine the supply and demand of taxi transport.

     The Chairman: Dr Yeo, guillotine time for this amendment is 1.00 pm.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Sir, I will try to go through the answers very quickly.

     The Chairman: You have to.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: The Chairman of the GPC, Dr Hong Hai, asked yesterday whether there are any predetermined targets for the number of passengers that we want to see on our MRT, the number of passengers that we want on buses, cars, taxis, the lot. The answer is no. This is not the way we plan our land transport system. We concentrate on the congestion created, and not on the absolute numbers using each of the different transport modes. But there are planning parameters which the bus companies and the MRTC use for their own internal planning. They are looking at approximately 2.8 million passenger trips per day on buses for the year up to 1995. And approximately 800,000 passenger trips per day on the MRT by the year 1995.

    The transport situation is not something that you can predetermine, come up with a number and say this is a number that we want to work to. Because the transport situation is a dynamic situation, dependent very much on the extent of usage which is in turn dependent on the state of the economy. All of us know that when the economy is doing well, more people travel, more people go for outings, for dinners, for visits to the Bird Park, beach and so on. So more trips result.

    The flow pattern of our traffic is also very important. You can have the same

Column: 668

number of trips made but if the trips are made outside of the CBD, they do not contribute to the congestion within. The Public Works Department looks at the overall flow of traffic throughout the island, in particular at three areas. Firstly, CBD for obvious reasons. This is where the highest concentration of employment is. Secondly, it looks at the flow of traffic through the inner ring roads going through Scotts Road, Patterson Road, and Newton Road. And then the outer roads which is Adam Road/Farrer Road going on to Queensway.

    The objective is to try to ensure that the flow of traffic throughout these three key areas does not suffer severe congestion. And if we are able to achieve traffic flow of about 90% of the capacity of the road design, then that would be give us a smooth flow. What is 90% of road capacity in terms of something that we can understand as motorists? 90% means that at a traffic junction, you will have to wait for one or two changes of light. In other words, you will have to meet the red light at most twice. That is roughly 90%. If you get too close to 100% of design capacity, you may have to wait three, four or even more times, more changes of light. With a good system for the distribution of traffic flow throughout the island, we can get closer to the 90% objective.

    Sir, the Chairman of GPC also touched upon the issue of privacy if we should move to having an electronic road pricing system. This concern has been expressed on a number of occasions to us. No decision has been taken on the ERP system that would be selected eventually. PWD is at the moment talking with the different manufacturers. Some systems go closer to the idea proposed by Dr Hong Hai which is to use "smart card" technology. Then each time that particular vehicle goes past the checkpoint, a certain sum of money is deducted. The technology is fairly complex. It has not completely stabilized yet. We do not know whether it is applicable to our circumstances. Other systems use simpler "read only" technology, which means that each time you go past, the detector reads the passage of a particular vehicle. We will look into the details bearing in mind Dr Hong's comments. However, I want to mention that

Column: 669

even if the read only technology is adopted rather than the "smart card" technology the question of privacy will still not be a serious one. Because the computer is not interested in who is in the car. The computer is only interested in whether a particular car has gone past and how much money has got to be deducted from the account holder.

    Sir, I move on very quickly to the comments made by the Member for Aljunied GRC, Encik Wan Hussin. I thank him for bringing to our attention the traffic situation in Kampong Ubi. I shall ask SBS to look into the details as to why the bus turned left instead of turning right when there is supposed to be more people on the right.

    Sir, Dr Low raised the question of whether we should be moving towards lead-free petrol. I believe this subject was raised earlier on with the Minister for the Environment. I have ascertained from the Ministry of the Environment that the present low level of lead in petrol is very satisfactory. It is the same as that used in many developed countries.

    As for noise pollution, the MCI is looking at the problem and ensuring that we keep up with the latest requirements worldwide, ensuring that our vehicles are as quiet as present technology. And this we will continue to do.

    Now I come to take up a number of questions raised by a large number of MPs on the question of taxi fares. The Member for Tanglin and the Member for Pasir Panjang GRC, Mr Lew and Dr Wan, have spoken very eloquently on the need to lower the diesel tax. They said that the diesel tax is too high. Dr Wan, together with Dr Beng, have gone further and said that the diesel tax is not relevant, that there is no anomaly. Sir, with your permission, I would like to circulate copies of a table (Cols. 739 - 740) to Members. [Copies of Table circulated to Members].
table - ANOMALIES IN TAXES FOR TAXIS AND CARS (Cols. 739 - 740)


    Sir, the table gives a list of the anomalies in taxes for taxis and cars. A taxi is a car with four wheels just like an ordinary car. It

Column: 670

may be painted blue and carries the label "NTUC Comfort" or it may be painted white and red and carries the label "Singapore Commuters Ltd". But a taxi is a car. And because a taxi is a car, it it contributes the same degree of congestion.

    Members can look at the table that I have just circulated and they will see that the duty on petrol is 50 cents per litre. The duty on diesel is 8.8 cents. There is a factor of approximately six times. The duty on petrol is approximately six times that of diesel. And the $6,600 is just a simple attempt to correct that anomaly. Going down the table, Sir, you will notice that the road tax for taxis is only $1,100, relative to the equivalent road tax for a 2-litre car of $2,100. So there is another area of discrepancy. Further down, if you look at the PARF payable, if a taxi were to be scrapped for a new taxi and if the scrapped taxi is less than five years old, there is no payment of ARF at all for the purchase of the new taxi. If the old taxi is less than six years old, there is only a $2,000 PARF, and if the taxi is less than seven years, it is $5,000. Compare that for the cars and we see another very large discrepancy.

    Sir, these are the anomalies that are in our present system. So the diesel tax just goes a small way in correcting that anomaly. The Government has decided to liberalize the taxi industry to permit market forces to determine the number of taxis on the road. The number of

    taxis on the road is determined by the taxi operators: NTUC Comfort, SCL and the other taxi operators. Taxi demand? That we leave to the market to decide. Taxi fare should be determined by taxi operators and not by the Government. Indeed, we have moved in that direction already, except that when we have built in as a safeguard the Public Transport Council which, Members will remember, was proposed by the former Government Parliamentary Committee on Communications and Information.

     Dr Hong Hai (Bedok GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head I be reduced by $10 in respect of Code IE 1500 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, the problem of our information programmes in Singapore is not that there are not enough news programmes or programmes of information and educational value. The problem is how to make them interesting enough so that people actually watch them and do not switch off.

    Sir, I was going to talk in general about this subject except that yesterday when the hon. Minister of State for Communications and Information responded to my suggestion on morning television, I was a little disappointed with the answer. The response to my suggestion was that the Ministry did not consider this to be a priority area at this time and had other more important things to look at. I feel that this answer is not entirely satisfactory and therefore I would like to now focus on this question a little more.

    One of the problems with our information and educational programmes, as I said, is that it is sometimes presented in a way that does not excite the interest of the audience. It is a difficult process to make the educational and information process interesting. This is why when my GPC thought about morning television, we felt that this might be a good way in which to marry the two objectives of SBC, the objective of informing and educating on the one hand and of entertaining on the other. The experience of television in the United States and in Hong Kong, as I have pointed out, is that morning programmes that are able to combine news, current affairs, discussions, talk shows, in a punchy and effective way are commercially very successful and draw large audiences. Hong Kong, in particular, has found this to be very effective and very

Column: 672

profitable and a great commercial success. In view of this, I was a little troubled that SBC does not consider this to be a priority area. I would like to ask the Minister of State to explain or give a compelling reason why in view of what can be achieved with such a programme, that is, marrying the two objectives of educating, informing and entertainment, why this is not given priority and whether SBC would like to re-think this subject.

     The Minister of State for Communications and Information (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Chairman, Sir, I thank the GPC Chairman for his comments. Unfortunately, since yesterday nothing has changed. SBC has not had any new information that would cause me to change my reply. However, before the GPC Chairman becomes even more disappointed, may I reassure him that in my answer yesterday I did not say that SBC is not going to do it but that it is not a priority item. In other words, the door is not closed to morning television programme. I think we can look forward to a programme of this nature which combines both educational elements as well as entertainment elements in a very well packaged manner. But unfortunately, given the resources that SBC has at its disposal at the moment, there are really other much more pressing things to do. I repeat though that the idea of packaging programmes which fulfill its objective of entertaining as well as informing, that SBC is fully in agreement with the Member. The question is how to do it, what are the resources available - in that sense I do not think the Member should be that disappointed with my reply.

     Dr Hong Hai: Sir, I do not mean to press the issue, but my question is, why is it not a priority item? My question is not why you do not do it today or right away? My question is, why do you regard it as not a priority item? In view of the substantial impact it could have in furthering the cause of making information interesting, why is it not a priority item? What are the other priorities that are so pressing that this has to be put aside for the moment?
